Posts.Title: PASH - Pseudoangiomatous stromal hyperplasia gillianinnh djmammo

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2013 09:18AM Grace1969 wrote: EJgirl, it's been a rough week! I had my PASH removed October 3, under general anesthesia, as an out patient. The evening of October 4, I noticed increased pain, swelling, dizziness and redness extending from my breast, up my chest to my neck. Went the the hospital's ER, that perform my wide local excision and was immediately admitted, rushed back to surgery, due to internal bleeding. There was 400 CCs of blood sitting in my breast and I lost another 100 CCs during surgery. My hemoglobin level dropped to 7.8. I stayed in the hospital for two days. I'm doing better, still fatigue and emotional. I didn't receive any drains during the first or second operation. I'm a little concern now, because I can hear fluid swishing around in the breast. Is that normal? No pressure, no pain and a little swelling.

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2013 08:44PM Grace1969 wrote: Sorry all...I should've gave some background information. Here goes... ((((July 2, 2013 I had my yearly mammogram. Informed on July 11 of a total of three abnormalities in both breast. July 16, mammo repeated in right breast and ultrasound performed on both breast. July 19, deep core biopsies perform on two oval shaped mass in my left breast (been there since my 2009 mammo, but I wasn't told about until now) and a spot in my right breast, that's new.)))) Pathology report came back today. The two oval shaped masses in the left breast are fibroids. The new lump in my right breast is PASH.
Posts.Title: Anyone heard of Pseudo-angiomatous stromal hyperplasia (PASH)? Grace1969 marie5890

Posts.Content: Grace1969 wrote: Pseudo-angiomatous stromal hyperplasia (PASH) is a rare and benign breast lesion. I'm being referred to a breast surgeon. Options may include wait and see, surgical removal of tumor or MX. Some PASH are even treated like breast cancer, as far as treatment. I'm so confused! I was ready for a cancer or benign DX. Not something that's rare and can mimic breast cancer. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Grace1969 wrote: July 2, 2013 I had my yearly mammogram. Informed on July 11th of a total of three abnormalities in both breast. July 16, mammo repeated in right breast and ultrasound performed on both breast. July 19, deep core biopsies perform on two oval shaped mass in my left breast (been there since my 2009 mammo, but I wasn't told about until now) and a spot in my right breast that's new. I'm now waiting for my results, which I have an appointment on July 26. We're a military family. My husband has been in the Air Force for almost 27 years, we've been married 22 years and we have three children ages 20, 17 and 10. With him being in the military, I've always taken care of everything and everyone. Now, I'm in this position of uncertainty and I need support, encouragement and reassurance, but he has totally checked out, since we were informed about the abnormalities. We have kids to take care of and we both don't have the luxury of checking out. He's gone to all my appointments, which is great!!! I'm doing the comforting and talking. I haven't seen any post addressing this issue with spouses. He's not a big communicator, so I don't know how he feels. Any insight or advice is more than welcomed. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy...Married, but feeling alone. Grace1969 Grace1969
